title: PE Daily: Gensler Talks Reform | Former Partner Sues Emerald Lake | True Wind Closes Second Fund
text:
Today's Top Stories

Wall Street's top regulator is considering new rules to bring sunshine to the private-funds market, including more disclosure about fees and conflicts of interest, Chris Cumming writes for WSJ Pro Private Equity. Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Gary Gensler said Wednesday he has asked agency staff for proposals to reform what he sees as a slate of troublesome practices by private-equity and hedge-fund managers. These include the use of unclear performance metrics and opacity in fees and expenses charged to investors.

True Wind Capital Management, a firm launched by two former senior investment professionals from KKR & Co., has rounded up $817 million for its second private-equity fund focused on information technology deals, Preeti Singh reports for WSJ Pro Private Equity. Although the San Francisco firm's fundraising process was disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic, the fund gained momentum in recent months and closed ahead of an $800 million goal.

A former partner of Emerald Lake Capital Management has sued the Los Angeles private-equity firm and its leadership, claiming they improperly fired her and then seized her financial interest in the firm, WSJ Pro Private Equity's Chris Cumming writes. Carling O'Brien sued the firm on Monday in the California Superior Court for the Western District of Los Angeles County on allegations that include breach of contract and defamation.

Upcoming Pro Event

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on Nov. 17. The program includes a discussion on sustainability in private markets with Megan Starr, global head of impact at The Carlyle Group. Register here.

Big Number

6.2%

The percentage jump in the consumer price index in October from a year earlier, the fastest 12-month inflation pace since 1990 and the fifth straight month of inflation above 5%.

Deals

Equinox Group LLC has obtained $255 million in new financing commitments from some of its lenders and owners, as the cash-strapped gym chain seeks to bolster its liquidity, Alexander Saeedy and Alexander Gladstone report for WSJ Pro Bankruptcy, citing people familiar with the matter. Lenders extending new financing include Bank of America Corp., Citigroup Inc. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc., these people said. Executives at property developer Related Cos. who own a stake in Equinox are also providing funds, according to the people familiar with the matter.

HGGC and Snapdragon Capital Partners have agreed to invest $240 million in healthcare technology company Fullscript. The company is an online platform that provides professional-grade supplements, adherence management and custom protocols, along with a library of resources about integrative medicine for practitioners. Fullscript plans to invest in technology, partnerships and acquisitions as a result of the transaction, according to a news release

TA Associates is acquiring a stake in Riskonnect Inc., a risk management technology provider backed by software-focused private-equity firm Thoma Bravo. Thoma Bravo, which acquired the company back in 2019, will retain a significant stake in Riskonnect, according to a press release.

Norwest Equity Partners has invested in Thibaut, a designer and supplier of wallcoverings, fabrics and furniture. Founded in 1866, the business is the U.S.'s oldest continuously operating wallpaper company, according to a news release about the deal. The new investment will help Thibaut expand its reach in product offerings, market channels and geographies.

Avego Healthcare Capital, the private equity arm of health-care focused investment firm Avego Management, has partnered with Ellie Diagnostics, a diagnostic provider for veterinarians. Ellie provides next-day lab results, complimentary shipping, pathology consultations, mobile access to orders and data protection for vets, among other services.

Paceline Equity Partners has agreed to buy flooring manufacturer AHF Products from fellow private-equity firm American Industrial Partners. American Industrial Partners indicated on its website that it backed the company out of American Industrial Partners Capital Fund VI LP, which closed in 2015 with $1.8 billion.

SPAC Track

New Providence Acquisition Corp II, a special purpose acquisition company co-led by Alex Coleman, the former co-head of Citicorp Venture Capital, has closed a $250 million upsized initial public offering. The SPAC said it aims to combine with a target with an expected market valuation ranging from $700 million to more than $1 billion.

Restaurant-technology business Presto is combining with a special-purpose acquisition company, going public with a valuation of about $1 billion, Amrith Ramkumar reports for the Journal. Presto offers technologies that aim to automate restaurants and improve dining experiences. The deal includes a roughly $70 million private investment in public equity, or PIPE.

Exits

The Hershey Company said that it has agreed to buy Pretzels Inc. from an affiliate of Peak Rock Capital. Separately, Hershey's is also buying Dot's Pretzels brand, which Pretzels Inc. co-manufactures, and paying roughly $1.2 billion for the two companies. The two businesses generated about $275 million in estimated aggregate net sales for the 12 months ending September 2021, according to a press release. Peak Rock initially announced it had acquired Pretzels Inc. in 2018.

Midmarket firm Transom Capital Group said it has sold outdoor lighting and door chime products company Heath Zenith, LLC to Globe Electric Company. Los Angeles-based Transom initially acquired the Bowling Green, Ky.-based company in 2016.

Stone Goff Partners said it has sold its investment in marketing technology provider The Channel Company to fellow private-equity firm Eagle Tree Capital. Stone Goff invested in The Channel Company back in 2016 and since then the company has nearly tripled its earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, according to a press release.

HIG Capital said it has sold direct-to-consumer flooring company Empire Today to fellow private-equity firm Charlesbank Capital Partners. HIG initially acquired the company in 2015.

Funds

StepStone Group Inc. has closed on more than $690 million for StepStone Tactical Growth Fund III. The vehicle integrates fund, secondary and co-investments, building exposure to technology and health-care assets, according to a news release about the fund's close. The strategy aims to provide exposure to venture capital and growth equity-backed companies.

Carnelian Energy Capital Management, a Houston-based firm that has historically focused on North American lower midmarket upstream oil and gas deals, is seeking $750 million for Carnelian Energy Capital IV LP, according to a regulatory filing. The offering amount is slightly lower than the $775 million that the firm raised for its third fund in 2019.

People

SVB Financial Group's private bank unit continues to grow its wealth management team with the addition of Natalya Alexei and Vishal Wadhwa as senior managing directors. Both were previously managing directors at Wells Fargo Private Bank.

Industry News

EQT AB announced that it had signed an agreement to acquire Life Science Partners, a European life sciences venture capital firm with some €2.2 billion, the equivalent of $2.53 billion, of assets under management. Headquartered in Amsterdam, the venture firm has invested in companies in the life sciences space and expects to generate some €37 million in revenues in 2021, according to a press release. It has backed some 150 life sciences companies since its founding in 1998, according to a news release about the deal.

Global asset manager GCM Grosvenor said in an earnings presentation that it raised $3 billion during the quarter ending Sep. 30, bringing its total fundraising for the first nine months of this year to $7 billion.
